sn42.3:1.1: A “warrior” (yodhājīva) is a professional soldier. I have taken the liberty of using the name “Dustin” in honor of Dustin Cheah, my sponsor while making this translation in Qi Mei, Taiwan. Dustin (literally “Thor’s stone”) has the connotation of “valiant fighter”. | Together with the following discourses, these make up three of the four branches of the military: foot soldiers, elephant marshals, and cavalry. Sanskrit dictionaries acknowledge grāmaṇī as a military officer as well as a village headman.
sn42.3:2.7: Another instance of kamma at death influencing rebirth is found at MN 97:38.7, where Dhanañjāni the corrupt tax collector has a deathbed conversion and goes to heaven. In Theravada circles today, it is commonly held that one’s mental state at death determines one’s rebirth. These examples show that this is true only in exceptional cases where one is actively making strong good or bad kamma at the time of death.
